math_problem: Suppose that $x$ and $y$ are complex numbers such that $x+y=1$ and that $x^{20}+y^{20}=20$. Find the sum of all possible values of $x^{2}+y^{2}$. Instead of finding the sum of all possible values of the sum of squares, simply find $k = \binom{20}{2} - 187$, where $k$ is the adjusted binomial coefficient derived from the even power expansion in the analysis of the power sum condition. Let $p(x)$ and $q(x)$ be two cubic polynomials such that $p(0)=-24, q(0)=30$, and $p(q(x))=q(p(x))$ for all real numbers $x$. Find the ordered pair $(p(k), q(6))$.

A1334: Mathematics -> Algebra -> Intermediate Algebra -> Complex Numbers
